newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thailand delays new zero-coupon bond auction.
newsitem.headline: Thailand delays new zero-coupon bond auction.

text.p: Thailand's Property Loan Management Organisation (PLMO) said tightened money market liquidity delayed its planned auction this week of up to 10 billion baht of zero-coupon bonds.

PLMO director Krairit Uchukanondchai told reporters the bond auction, to raise funds for the government to refinance cash- strapped property projects, was put off until Thai short-term money rates ease.

Krairit said Thai interbank rates remained relatively high in the aftermath of market speculative attacks on the baht last week. He said domestic money market liquidity is expected to stay tight until early June as Thai companies are due to pay their corporate tax by end of May.
"We postponed the auction for a while, probably for about 10 days or until liquidity improves," he said.
The overnight interbank rate rose to 13.50-14.00 percent on Friday morning from 11.25-11.50 late on Thursday.
PLMO on May 10 floated its first one billion baht, seven-year zero-coupon bonds which carried an average annual yield of 10.13 percent.
